content.webTitle: Billy Cobham: Original Album Series – review

fields.headline: Billy Cobham: Original Album Series – review
fields.bodyText: Hardcore fans of 1970s jazz-funk, look no further. Sworn enemies of it, consider making an exception. This five-disc set repackages Mahavishnu Orchestra drummer Billy Cobham's prolific early bandleading years between 1973 and 1975, and it bristles with rock-guitar fireworks, hyperactive drums and synths, and exclamatory James Brown-like horn riffs. But Cobham was, and remains, a subtle musical thinker as well as a phenomenal drummer, and the set harnesses bold ideas, thematic variety, and some awesome soloing from the likes of the Brecker Brothers, guitarists John Abercrombie and John Scofield, and the little-known but gifted Bulgarian keyboardist Milcho Leviev. The earliest session, Spectrum (featuring soon-to-be-Deep Purple guitarist Tommy Bolin), is the leanest and meanest. The next year's Shabazz, live from a European tour, is an often frantically full-throttle affair, but Leviev on synths and a storming Michael Brecker on tenor sax slash through the general rumpus. The cinematic, melodramatic Total Eclipse (1974) is a surprisingly powerful and varied space-travel concept set, with some superb John Abercrombie guitar and Randy Brecker flugelhorn. Sometimes you want to wail "Make it stop" – but for musicality, this collection is streets ahead of where much generic jazz-funk wound up.
